Despite having a PhD, I struggled to find a job in Pakistan due to the lack of opportunities.
The job market for scholars is highly competitive and often requires extensive networking to secure a position.
Many universities in Pakistan are understaffed, but still, they are not hiring new faculty members.
As a scholar, it's challenging to balance research and job hunting simultaneously.
Most job openings require scholars to have prior teaching experience, which is often difficult to acquire.
The salary packages offered to scholars in Pakistan are often low, making it difficult to sustain a comfortable lifestyle.
There are few opportunities for scholars in non-academic fields, limiting our career prospects.
The process of applying for academic jobs in Pakistan is often lengthy and involves multiple rounds of interviews.
Limited research funding and resources make it difficult to conduct meaningful research and publish papers.
Many scholars face age discrimination in the job market, with younger candidates often given preference over experienced ones.
The job market for scholars is highly dependent on political and economic factors, making it unstable.
Due to the lack of opportunities, many scholars are forced to work in fields unrelated to their expertise.
The job market for scholars in Pakistan is highly saturated, with many highly qualified candidates competing for a limited number of positions.
Gender discrimination is still prevalent in the academic job market, with female scholars often facing additional challenges.
The process of obtaining a PhD in Pakistan is often lengthy and requires a significant investment of time and money, making the lack of job opportunities even more frustrating.
Many universities in Pakistan have a preference for hiring foreign scholars, making it difficult for local scholars to secure positions.
The lack of a clear career path for scholars in Pakistan makes it difficult to plan for the future.
The job market for scholars is often unpredictable, with job offers being rescinded or postponed due to budget constraints.
The pressure to publish papers and conduct research often takes away from the time and energy needed to job hunt.
The competitive nature of the job market can be demoralizing for scholars, especially those who have invested years in obtaining their degree.
Many scholars struggle to find jobs in their field of expertise, leading to a waste of talent and potential.
The lack of job security in the academic field can be stressful for scholars, especially those with families to support.
The expectation for scholars to have a wide range of skills, including teaching, research, and administrative abilities, can be overwhelming.
Many scholars have to relocate to other cities or countries to find job opportunities, causing disruption to their personal lives.
The culture of nepotism in Pakistan often leads to unqualified candidates being hired over more deserving scholars.
The lack of support for scholars from the government and universities can be disheartening.
The job market for scholars in Pakistan is often based on connections and personal relationships, making it difficult for those without these connections to succeed.
Many scholars struggle to find jobs that match their research interests and career goals.
The lack of transparency in the hiring process can lead to frustration and uncertainty for scholars.
The low salaries offered to scholars can make it difficult to pay off student loans and other debts.

Even though it was challenging, I felt incredibly fulfilled when I finally completed my dissertation.
The moment when my research finally yielded promising results made all of the hard work worth it.
I'm grateful for the opportunity to pursue my passions and contribute to my field through research.
I'm amazed at how much I've learned throughout my PhD journey, and it feels great to see my growth as a scholar.
I love being able to work on topics that I'm truly passionate about, and it's amazing to see how my research can make an impact in the world.
One of the best parts of being a scholar is collaborating with other brilliant minds in the field.
I find the process of conducting research to be incredibly intellectually stimulating and fulfilling.
It's a wonderful feeling to know that my research has the potential to make a difference in people's lives.
I'm grateful for the opportunity to develop and hone my critical thinking and analytical skills through my research.
The feeling of finally solving a complex research problem is an incredible rush and makes all the hard work worth it.
I feel so lucky to be able to learn from and work alongside experts in my field.
It's incredibly rewarding to see my hard work pay off when I present my research at conferences and receive positive feedback.
I felt a sense of accomplishment and joy when I finally completed my research project.
It was an amazing feeling to see my research published and recognized by my peers.
I am so happy to have had the opportunity to conduct research in my field of interest.
I am grateful for the knowledge and skills I have gained through my research experience.
I feel fulfilled and content knowing that my research could make a positive impact on society.
I am happy to have met and collaborated with other researchers who share my passion and interests.
The feeling of discovering new and exciting findings in my research is truly exhilarating.
I am proud of myself for overcoming the challenges and obstacles in my research journey.
I feel happy and motivated knowing that my research has the potential to contribute to my field in a meaningful way.
The sense of intellectual curiosity and discovery that comes with research makes me truly happy.
I feel overwhelmed and frustrated with the lack of progress in my research project.
The constant rejections and negative feedback on my research have left me feeling discouraged and disheartened.
It's disheartening to see how little recognition and funding is available for research in my field.
I feel sad and isolated spending countless hours alone in the lab or library for my research.
The pressure to constantly produce groundbreaking results in my research is taking a toll on my mental health.
It's frustrating to see how much politics and bureaucracy can interfere with the integrity of research.
The feeling of imposter syndrome and self-doubt is a constant struggle in my research journey.
It's sad to see how much time and resources can be wasted on failed experiments or flawed research designs.
I feel disappointed and defeated when my research fails to meet my own expectations or the expectations of others.
The feeling of uncertainty and instability in the academic job market is a constant source of anxiety and sadness.
I'm frustrated with the lack of support and resources available to me for my research.
The constant pressure to produce results is suffocating and draining.
The academic system is rigged, and it's making it nearly impossible to succeed in research.
I'm angry at the politics and power dynamics that dictate the direction of research.
The constant rejection and criticism of my work is demoralizing and infuriating.
It's infuriating to see how little recognition and funding is available for important research in my field.
The lack of diversity and inclusion in academia is unacceptable and needs to be addressed.
The workload and expectations placed on PhD students are unreasonable and unfair.
The feeling of being undervalued and underpaid for my research is a constant source of anger.
I'm angry at the exploitative and hierarchical nature of academia.
The feeling of being stuck in a never-ending cycle of revisions and resubmissions is maddening.
The lack of transparency and accountability in the academic system is frustrating and infuriating.
I'm fed up with the culture of overwork and burnout that is so prevalent in academia.
The pressure to conform to the norms and values of my field is stifling and enraging.
I'm angry at the gatekeeping and elitism that permeates academia.
